newsitem.title: USA: Sprint, Viacom in Blockbuster/Internet deal.
newsitem.headline: Sprint, Viacom in Blockbuster/Internet deal.

text.p: Sprint Corp and Viacom Inc's Blockbuster Entertainment Group on Thursday said they were offering a free Internet access software package via Blockbuster's 3,200 music and video stores across the U.S.
"Blockbuster can be every family's ticket to the entertainment experiences available on the Internet," said Tom Byrne, vice chairman of Blockbuster.

Confirming an earlier Reuters story, the two said they would combine Sprint's Internet access product with software focused on entertainment to provide music and video clips from a Blockbuster home page. Users can buy music online.
Sprint's Internet Passport software, which uses a customized version of Netscape Communications Corp's Navigator, will be provided free with a Blockbuster video or music rental or purchase.
The partners plan to support the launch with an advertising blitz in 50 cities this month. Blockbuster will also mail the promotion to its six million video members.

The software includes includes an electronic white pages -- telephone directory -- for the entire U.S., and a listing of online stores where users may shop. Later the partners will add online games, chatlines and electronic shopping for books, videos and games.
Though the software is free, and comes on a CD-ROM, users will still need to pay monthly $19.95 flat monthly Internet access fee, or $1.50 per hour to use the service after a first free month.
Users do not need to be customers of Sprint's long distance service.
